passage_text: Occupational Therapist Salary. Occupational therapists employed in the United States generally report earning salaries in the range from $49,858 to $92,511 a year including bonuses, which can amount to up to $3,050 a year according to the salary information provided by Payscale. The hourly wage varies depending on work experience among other factors. Occupational therapists with 1 to 4 years of experience generally earn between $24.54 and $43.53 per hour, and those with 5 to 9 years of work experience are typically paid between $28.44 and $49.60 per hour.

The highest pay showed in home health care services, with mean salaries of $41.13 per hour, or $85,540 per year. As with PTs, California offered the best employment for occupational therapists, though average salaries were lower at $40.74 per hour, or $84,750 per year. The state with the most jobs was California, where average salaries were $41.78 per hour, or $86.890 per year. However, the one with the best pay was Nevada, with mean wages of $47.03 per hour, or $97,810 per year. Related Reading: Adapted Physical Education vs. Occupational Therapy.

The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) stated that as of May 2013, the median annual wage of physical therapists was $81,030, with the top ten percent taking home $113,340 or more. The BLS anticipates a 36% growth of employment in physical therapy from 2012-2022. All physical therapists must earn a doctoral degree in the field, which usually takes three years, and be licensed by the state in which they practice. Career opportunities for doctors of physical therapy are projected to rise faster than the national average for all occupations.
